title: How to Clean Greasy Kitchen Cabinets

steps.headline: Create a vinegar solution.
steps.description: Pour undiluted distilled white vinegar into a spray bottle. If your cabinets have a delicate finish, make a gentler vinegar cleaning solution by adding equal parts of vinegar and warm water to the spray bottle. If you don’t have a spray bottle at home, you can purchase one at most grocery stores, hardware stores, and general retailers. Vinegar is especially good at removing the sticky film sometimes left behind by hands. If you have small children who leave greasy handprints on your cabinets, use vinegar.

steps.headline: Mist your greasy cabinets with the vinegar solution.
steps.description: Be thorough when misting. Coat all surfaces of the cabinets with a light layer of the vinegar solution. After applying the solution, allow it to sit for about 5 to 10 minutes. Do not oversaturate your cabinets with the solution. This can cause wood damage, peeling paint, or rusting metal.

steps.headline: Re-wet the cabinets and wipe them clean.
steps.description: After the vinegar has had time to sit, mist the cabinets again in the same fashion as before. Then use a clean, soft dishcloth to scrub away built up grease and grime.

steps.headline: Use a gentle scrubber on stubborn areas.
steps.description: Severely dirty cabinets may require light buffing with a non-abrasive scrubbing pad. Lightly rub the scrubber in a circular motion over areas with stubborn grease. Using abrasive cleaning tools may harm the finish or the surface of your cabinets. Test scrubbers on an out of sight part of the cabinet before using them.

steps.headline: Dry the cleaned cabinets.
steps.description: Use a clean, soft, lint-free cloth to wipe your cabinets dry. When the cabinets are dry, you should be able to see or feel any remaining greasiness. Repeat this process as necessary until your cabinets are grease free.

methods.name: Cutting through Moderate Grease with a Detergent

steps.headline: Prepare the detergent solution.
steps.description: Fill a bucket with warm water and add a moderate amount of oil or grease cutting dish soap to it. If you plan to use a laundry detergent, in most cases you'll need to add a cup (237 ml) of detergent for every 2 cups (473 ml) of water. Stir the solution to distribute the soap in the water. Some detergents or soaps may be in concentrated form. In these cases, you may need to reduce the amount used. Follow the label directions of your cleaner for the best results. EXPERT TIP																															James Sears																Cleaning Guru								James Sears leads the customer happiness team at Neatly, a group of cleaning gurus based in Los Angeles and Orange County, California. James is an expert in all things clean and provides transformative experiences by reducing clutter and renewing your home environment. James is a current Trustee Scholar at the University of Southern California. James Sears			Cleaning Guru				Our Expert Agrees: Make a cleaning few drops of dishwashing liquid and water. Apply this solution to any sticky areas, then wipe or scrub the cabinets with a microfiber cloth.

steps.headline: Apply the detergent with a dishcloth.
steps.description: Dip a soft, lint-free dishcloth into your detergent solution. Wring out excess solution in the bucket. Wipe all surfaces of your cabinets with the wet cloth to distribute a light coating of solution on the cabinets. For severe grease, allow the solution to sit for about five minutes. Take care to only lightly apply cleaner to the surface of your cabinets. Using too much solution may cause damage to the finish of your cabinets.

steps.headline: Wipe the cabinets clean of grease.
steps.description: Wet your dishcloth again in the detergent solution and wring out excess moisture. Wipe the cabinets thoroughly with the cloth to remove grease and any other buildup. When your cloth becomes dirty, rinse it by dunking it in the water and wringing it out again. Stubborn grease may need some scrubbing action to remove. Only use scrubbers that aren’t abrasive. Always test scrubbers on an inconspicuous part of the cabinet before scrubbing visible portions.

steps.headline: Wipe remaining surface moisture from the cabinets.
steps.description: Use a fresh, lint-free cloth to wipe away any leftover detergent solution or water. After that, inspect your cabinets for missed grease or grime. Reapply the cleaning solution in the process described to remove lingering grease.

methods.name: Treating Heavy Grease with Baking Soda

steps.headline: Create a paste with baking soda and vegetable oil.
steps.description: In a small mixing bowl, combine two parts baking soda with one part vegetable oil. With your clean fingers or a kitchen utensil, mix the soda and oil until it forms a thick, well blended paste. Make enough paste to lightly coat all greasy surfaces of your cabinets. As an example, if you plan on using 2 tbsp (30 ml) of oil, you’d need to use 4 tbsp (59 ml) of baking soda. Alternatively, you could substitute mineral oil in place of vegetable oil. Use the same amount of mineral oil as you would vegetable oil. Test this paste on an out of sight spot on your cabinets. Some finishes may react negatively to baking soda’s mild abrasive properties.

steps.headline: Cover the area beneath your cabinets.
steps.description: The cleaning paste should be quite thick. While cleaning your cabinets, it’s likely that some of this paste will fall onto the area beneath them, along with absorbed grease and grime. Lay out a cover, like newspaper, a drop cloth, or an old towel, under your cabinets to catch falling paste.

steps.headline: Apply the paste to the cabinets with your clean fingers.
steps.description: Scoop up a small amount of the paste with your fingers. Gently rub the paste onto all dirty surfaces of the cabinet in a thin coat. Pay close attention to handles, where grease and buildup collect naturally.

steps.headline: Scrub the paste to remove grease.
steps.description: Use a non-abrasive sponge or soft, lint-free dishcloth to lightly scrub the paste on your cabinets. Work it into nooks, crannies, and cracks in the grain. For narrow spaces or detail cleaning, use a toothbrush.

steps.headline: Remove the paste and wipe the cabinets dry.
steps.description: Cleanse your sponge or dishcloth by rinsing it in clean water. When clean, wring it out so it is damp. Wipe away any paste still on your cabinets with the sponge or cloth. Dry the surface of the cabinets with a soft, lint-free drying cloth. If any grease remains, spot clean it with leftover paste in the fashion described. When your cabinets are clean, remaining paste can be thrown away.

text: Eliminating Light Grease with Vinegar Create a vinegar solution. Pour undiluted distilled white vinegar into a spray bottle. If your cabinets have a delicate finish, make a gentler vinegar cleaning solution by adding equal parts of vinegar and warm water to the spray bottle. If you don’t have a spray bottle at home, you can purchase one at most grocery stores, hardware stores, and general retailers. Vinegar is especially good at removing the sticky film sometimes left behind by hands. If you have small children who leave greasy handprints on your cabinets, use vinegar. Mist your greasy cabinets with the vinegar solution. Be thorough when misting. Coat all surfaces of the cabinets with a light layer of the vinegar solution. After applying the solution, allow it to sit for about 5 to 10 minutes. Do not oversaturate your cabinets with the solution. This can cause wood damage, peeling paint, or rusting metal. Re-wet the cabinets and wipe them clean. After the vinegar has had time to sit, mist the cabinets again in the same fashion as before. Then use a clean, soft dishcloth to scrub away built up grease and grime. Use a gentle scrubber on stubborn areas. Severely dirty cabinets may require light buffing with a non-abrasive scrubbing pad. Lightly rub the scrubber in a circular motion over areas with stubborn grease. Using abrasive cleaning tools may harm the finish or the surface of your cabinets. Test scrubbers on an out of sight part of the cabinet before using them. Dry the cleaned cabinets. Use a clean, soft, lint-free cloth to wipe your cabinets dry. When the cabinets are dry, you should be able to see or feel any remaining greasiness. Repeat this process as necessary until your cabinets are grease free. Cutting through Moderate Grease with a Detergent Prepare the detergent solution. Fill a bucket with warm water and add a moderate amount of oil or grease cutting dish soap to it. If you plan to use a laundry detergent, in most cases you'll need to add a cup (237 ml) of detergent for every 2 cups (473 ml) of water. Stir the solution to distribute the soap in the water. Some detergents or soaps may be in concentrated form. In these cases, you may need to reduce the amount used. Follow the label directions of your cleaner for the best results. EXPERT TIP																															James Sears																Cleaning Guru								James Sears leads the customer happiness team at Neatly, a group of cleaning gurus based in Los Angeles and Orange County, California. James is an expert in all things clean and provides transformative experiences by reducing clutter and renewing your home environment. James is a current Trustee Scholar at the University of Southern California. James Sears			Cleaning Guru				Our Expert Agrees: Make a cleaning few drops of dishwashing liquid and water. Apply this solution to any sticky areas, then wipe or scrub the cabinets with a microfiber cloth. Apply the detergent with a dishcloth. Dip a soft, lint-free dishcloth into your detergent solution. Wring out excess solution in the bucket. Wipe all surfaces of your cabinets with the wet cloth to distribute a light coating of solution on the cabinets. For severe grease, allow the solution to sit for about five minutes. Take care to only lightly apply cleaner to the surface of your cabinets. Using too much solution may cause damage to the finish of your cabinets. Wipe the cabinets clean of grease. Wet your dishcloth again in the detergent solution and wring out excess moisture. Wipe the cabinets thoroughly with the cloth to remove grease and any other buildup. When your cloth becomes dirty, rinse it by dunking it in the water and wringing it out again. Stubborn grease may need some scrubbing action to remove. Only use scrubbers that aren’t abrasive. Always test scrubbers on an inconspicuous part of the cabinet before scrubbing visible portions. Wipe remaining surface moisture from the cabinets. Use a fresh, lint-free cloth to wipe away any leftover detergent solution or water. After that, inspect your cabinets for missed grease or grime. Reapply the cleaning solution in the process described to remove lingering grease. Treating Heavy Grease with Baking Soda Create a paste with baking soda and vegetable oil. In a small mixing bowl, combine two parts baking soda with one part vegetable oil. With your clean fingers or a kitchen utensil, mix the soda and oil until it forms a thick, well blended paste. Make enough paste to lightly coat all greasy surfaces of your cabinets. As an example, if you plan on using 2 tbsp (30 ml) of oil, you’d need to use 4 tbsp (59 ml) of baking soda. Alternatively, you could substitute mineral oil in place of vegetable oil. Use the same amount of mineral oil as you would vegetable oil. Test this paste on an out of sight spot on your cabinets. Some finishes may react negatively to baking soda’s mild abrasive properties. Cover the area beneath your cabinets. The cleaning paste should be quite thick. While cleaning your cabinets, it’s likely that some of this paste will fall onto the area beneath them, along with absorbed grease and grime. Lay out a cover, like newspaper, a drop cloth, or an old towel, under your cabinets to catch falling paste. Apply the paste to the cabinets with your clean fingers. Scoop up a small amount of the paste with your fingers. Gently rub the paste onto all dirty surfaces of the cabinet in a thin coat. Pay close attention to handles, where grease and buildup collect naturally. Scrub the paste to remove grease. Use a non-abrasive sponge or soft, lint-free dishcloth to lightly scrub the paste on your cabinets. Work it into nooks, crannies, and cracks in the grain. For narrow spaces or detail cleaning, use a toothbrush. Remove the paste and wipe the cabinets dry. Cleanse your sponge or dishcloth by rinsing it in clean water. When clean, wring it out so it is damp. Wipe away any paste still on your cabinets with the sponge or cloth. Dry the surface of the cabinets with a soft, lint-free drying cloth. If any grease remains, spot clean it with leftover paste in the fashion described. When your cabinets are clean, remaining paste can be thrown away.

If you plan to use a laundry detergent, in most cases you'll need to add a cup (237 ml) of detergent for every 2 cups (473 ml) of water.
Stir the solution to distribute the soap in the water.
Some detergents or soaps may be in concentrated form.
In these cases, you may need to reduce the amount used.
Follow the label directions of your cleaner for the best results.

Treating Heavy Grease with Baking Soda Create a paste with baking soda and vegetable oil.

With your clean fingers or a kitchen utensil, mix the soda and oil until it forms a thick, well blended paste.
Make enough paste to lightly coat all greasy surfaces of your cabinets.
As an example, if you plan on using 2 tbsp (30 ml) of oil, you’d need to use 4 tbsp (59 ml) of baking soda.

Cover the area beneath your cabinets.
The cleaning paste should be quite thick.
While cleaning your cabinets, it’s likely that some of this paste will fall onto the area beneath them, along with absorbed grease and grime.

Gently rub the paste onto all dirty surfaces of the cabinet in a thin coat.
Pay close attention to handles, where grease and buildup collect naturally.
Scrub the paste to remove grease.
Use a non-abrasive sponge or soft, lint-free dishcloth to lightly scrub the paste on your cabinets.
Work it into nooks, crannies, and cracks in the grain.
For narrow spaces or detail cleaning, use a toothbrush.
Remove the paste and wipe the cabinets dry.
Cleanse your sponge or dishcloth by rinsing it in clean water.
When clean, wring it out so it is damp.
Wipe away any paste still on your cabinets with the sponge or cloth.
Dry the surface of the cabinets with a soft, lint-free drying cloth.
If any grease remains, spot clean it with leftover paste in the fashion described.
When your cabinets are clean, remaining paste can be thrown away.
